Question.CompentancyDescription: Describe types and uses of air samples.
Question.CompentancyTopic: Sampling Strategies and Air Sampling Results
Question.STS_Line: • 4.5.2.1 Types of air samples
Question.Training_Reference:
• AIHA, The Occupational Environment: Its Evaluation, Control and Management
  • Fundamentals of Industrial Hygiene
Question.QuestionText: Determine whether each phrase below accurately completes the statement, "Air sampling is ____________________."
Question.InstructionText: Select the appropriate column for each item, then click Done.

Options.Option: Used to determine the need for further sampling
Used as the sole determining factor to evaluate the worst case scenario for exposure
Used to determine if the exposure exceeds threshold levels
Used only as an indirect method
Required to be analyzed by a certified lab to be useful to a commander

Question.QuestionText: Which of the following are steps involved in interpreting air sampling results?
Question.InstructionText:
Select all that apply,
then click Done.

Options.Option: Determine if additive/synergistic health effects exist

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify basic facts about environmental health threat sampling.

Question.Training_Reference:
• AFMAN 48-154, Occupational and Environmental Health Site Assessment
  • OEHSA Documentation and Data Management Technical Guide
Question.QuestionText: Which two of the following purposes best describe what background environmental health threat sampling provides?
Question.InstructionText:
Select all that apply,
then click Done.

Options.Option: Categorization of industrial hazards that may migrate into non-industrial workplaces
Identification of natural “clusters” of personnel to establish homogeneous groups
Environmental Health Risk Assessments of ambient environmental conditions
Background data for comparison to source-specific environmental health hazards

Options.Option: Vary the method and conditions of sampling
Increase the number of samples taken
Decrease the number of samples taken

Question.CompentancyDescription: State the purpose of a sanitary survey.
Question.CompentancyTopic: Environmental Analysis and Sanitary Surveys
Question.STS_Line: • 4.15.1.12 Base sanitary surveys
Question.Training_Reference: • AFI 48-144, Safe Drinking Water Surveillance Program
Question.QuestionText: Which statement best describes the purpose of a sanitary survey?
Question.InstructionText:
Select the correct answer,
then click Done.

Options.Option: To evaluate the adequacy of each component of a public water system to produce and distribute safe drinking water
To identify vulnerabilities in a water distribution system that could be subject to tampering, sabotage, and contamination
To conduct emergency disinfection of water mains, storage tanks, and treatment facilities to make the water safe for drinking
To perform analysis of samples from ice machines plumbed to potable water systems to rule out bacteriological contamination

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify the purpose of a water vulnerability assessment.
Question.CompentancyTopic: Water Vulnerability Assessment and Water Sampling
Question.STS_Line: • 4.15.1.14 Water vulnerability assessment
Question.Training_Reference:
• AFI 10-246, Food and Water Protection Program
  • AFI 48-144, Safe Drinking Water Surveillance Program
  • AFIOH Water Vulnerability and Risk Assessments for Potable Water Assets
Question.QuestionText: Which of the following best describes the purpose of a Water Vulnerability Assessment?
Question.InstructionText:
Select the correct answer,
then click Done.

Options.Option: To evaluate the adequacy of each component of a public water system to produce and distribute safe drinking water
To identify areas in a water distribution system that could be subject to tampering, sabotage, and contamination
To conduct emergency disinfection of water mains, storage tanks, and treatment facilities to make the water safe for drinking
To perform analysis of samples from ice machines plumbed to potable water systems to rule out possible bacteriological contamination

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify various CBRN sampling equipment and their capabilities.
Question.CompentancyTopic: Sampling Strategies and Air Sampling Results
Question.STS_Line:
• 4.5.2.2 Air sampling devices
  • 4.5.3.4 Soil/solid sampling devices
  • 4.5.3.4.2 FT-IR
  • 4.9.2.11.2 Gamma Spec (i.e. SAM-940)
  • 4.9.2.11.3 Geiger-Mueller (i.e. ADM-300)
  • 4.9.2.11.4 EPD (i.e. MK-2 & N-2)
  • 4.15.3.5 Water sampling devices
Question.Training_Reference:
• ADM-300 User's Manual
  • CDS Kit User's Manual
  • EPD User's Manual
  • HAPSITE User's Manual
  • SAM 940 Field Guide
  • TM 3-6665-307-10, M256-Series Chemical Agent Detector Kit
Question.QuestionText: Match each type of CBRN equipment with its capabilities.
Question.InstructionText: Drag the items to the appropriate locations, then click Done.

Options.Option:
Portable Gas Chromatograph/Mass Spectrometer
Requires nitrogen and a mixture of trifluoromethylbenzene and bromopentafluorobenzene in order to operate

Portable gamma spectroscopy surveillance and measurement system
Identifies multiple nuclides by their photon energies and detects neutrons
Automatically subtracts background

Provides "real-time" updates of individual radiation dose and dose-rate
Has both audible and visual alarms

Measures gamma radiation and detects beta
Uses external probes for Alpha, Beta, Gamma, and X-Ray

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify properties associated with radionuclide half-lives.
Question.CompentancyTopic: Water Vulnerability Assessment and Water Sampling
Question.STS_Line:
• 6.6.1 Radioactive half-life
  • 6.6.2 Biological half-life
  • 6.6.3 Effective half-life (establish relationship)
Question.Training_Reference:
• Bioenvironmental Engineer’s Guide to Ionizing Radiation
  • DoD 3150.8-M, Nuclear Accident Response Procedures
Question.QuestionText: Match the type of radionuclide half-life with its definition.
Question.InstructionText: Select the appropriate column for each item, then click Done.

Options.Option: The time in which the quantity of an isotope in the body shall decrease to half because of radioactive decay and biological elimination
The time required for the activity of a given radioactive element to decrease to half of its initial value due to radioactive decay
The time required for the body to eliminate one-half of a radioactive element which has been introduced into it

Question.QuestionText:
You are collecting air samples at a nuclear weapons accident with Pu as the suspected airborne contaminant. Using an ADM-300 with AP-100 probe, Whatman #41 8” x 10” filters, and a count rate of 170 cpm, what is the activity concentration given the following information?

Detection efficiency – 0.0825
Average flow rate – 45 ft /min
Airborne particle retention – 0.74
Air sampling time – 60 minutes
Question.InstructionText:
Select the correct answer, then click Done.
For assistance, click the Lifeline.

Question.QuestionText: During the analysis phase of a TIC/TIM vulnerability assessment, which two of the following are determined while developing worst-case and alternative scenarios?
Question.InstructionText: Select all that apply, then click Done.

Options.Option: The maximum volume of the largest single container if there are multiple containers at one location
The range of a chemical that will be released for a worst-case scenario
The release type, duration, and height of a chemical for plume modeling
The level of concern for a chemical to cause death or severe injury/illness

then click Done.

Options.Option: The movement of chemicals through zippers, seams, or imperfections in a protective clothing material
The process by which a chemical dissolves in or moves through a material as a result of a concentration gradient

Physical changes in a material as the result of a chemical exposure, use, or ambient conditions

Question.QuestionText: Which two of the following best describe major limitations of the flame ionization detector (FID) in the TVA-100B?

Cannot detect the presence of methane gas
Affected by CO, CO<font size='10'>2</font> and water vapor concentrations
Not for use when there is a potential for explosion

Question.QuestionText: Which of the detector statements below are true and which statements are false?
Question.InstructionText: Select the appropriate column for each item, then click Done.

Options.Option: The CDS Kit can detect and measure Lewisite as low as 3 mg/m³
SAM 940 contains trigger lists and enables users to search for specific isotopes
ADM-300A can detect and identify multiple nuclides by their photon energies

In order for a chemical to be detected by the HAPSITE it must be organic,
be within a pH range of 2-11, and have a boiling point below 250 degrees C
The M256 Kit detects Nerve, Blister, Choking, and Blood Agents in the vapor form

Question.CompentancyDescription: Determine correct air sampling pump calibration procedures.
Question.STS_Line:
• 3.2.1 Solve calculations using basic arithmetic functions (add, subtract, multiply, and divide whole numbers, fractions, and decimals)
  • 3.2.2 Perform conversion of units using dimensional analysis (formula manipulation), metric conversions
  • 4.5.1.2 OEH sample guide (include USAPHC guide)
  • 4.5.2.7 Calibrate air sampling pumps
Question.Training_Reference:
• Fundamentals of Industrial Hygiene
  • USAFSAM Laboratory Sampling Guide
Question.QuestionText: Using a primary standard soap-bubble meter with a 1,000 ml burette, put the steps for calibrating an air sampling pump in the correct order.
Question.InstructionText: Drag the items to the appropriate locations, then click Done.

target_options.target_option: Adjust pump flow rate until desired flow rate is achieved
Assemble sample train (burette, filter, and pump)
Run pump at least 5 minutes and check voltage
Draw 2 or 3 bubbles up the burette to ensure they will reach the top
Wet the inside of the burette with soap solution
Verify the flow rate at least 2 times
Capture a single bubble and time from 0 to 1,000 ml
Momentarily submerge the burette opening to capture a film of soap

Question.CompentancyDescription: Identify disposal methods for radioactive material with the AFRRAD office.
Question.STS_Line: • 4.9.2.17 Disposal methods for radioactive material with Air Force Radiation and Radioactive Recycling and Disposal (AFRRAD) office
Question.Training_Reference: • AFI 40-201, Managing Radioactive Materials in the US Air Force
Question.QuestionText: Exempt quantity items (e.g., electron tubes and spark gaps) containing radioactive material can be disposed of as normal trash provided which of the following two conditions are satisfied?
Question.InstructionText: Select all that apply, then click Done.

Options.Option: Electron tubes or spark gaps are stored to prevent breakage
Each electron tube or spark gap contains less than quantities listed in 10 CFR 30.15
Radiation from each electron tube or spark gap does not exceed 0.1 milliRoentgen per hour on contact
Radiation from the outside surface of the electron tube or spark gap package does not exceed 2 milliRoentgen per hour

Question.CompentancyDescription: Calculate radiation activity concentration.
Question.STS_Line:
• 3.2.1 Solve calculations using basic arithmetic functions (add, subtract, multiply, and divide whole numbers, fractions, and decimals)
  • 4.9.2.10.1 Perform field analysis of samples (utilizing probe efficiency)
Question.Training_Reference: • Bioenvironmental Engineer’s Guide to Ionizing Radiation
Question.QuestionText:
You are air sampling a process with depleted uranium as the primary airborne contaminant. Using an ADM-300 with AP-100 probe, Whatman 934-AH round (3 cm diameter) filters, and a count rate of 103 cpm, what is the activity concentration given the following information?

Detection efficiency – 0.0825
Average flow rate – 25 ft /min
Airborne particle retention – 0.999
Air sampling time – 120 minutes
Question.InstructionText:
Select the correct answer, then click Done.
For assistance, click the Lifeline.

Question.QuestionText: During the data collection phase of a TIC/TIM vulnerability assessment, which two of the following items of information are required when collecting off-base, on-base, and transportation TIC/TIM data?

Options.Option: The type and height of a chemical release
Location of the material and its latitude/longitude
The range of a chemical that will be released for a worst-case scenario
